Crafting Music with interactive training
Our teaching philosophy is centered around immersive, hands-on learning that drives you toward creating a tangible final project. We believe in achieving real results in a fun, inspiring, and creative environment, where every lesson brings you closer to becoming the music producer you aspire to be.
Tailored Instruction in a Small Group Setting
You'll be part of an intimate group, typically with just five students, allowing for maximum interaction with your instructor and personalized guidance. Each class introduces new concepts that youâ€™ll immediately apply in your projects, ensuring that the knowledge sticks and that you see your progress in real-time.

Collective Resources

Course Curriculum

Transform Your Talent Into a Career with Our Artist Development Program
2.1 Understanding the Nature of Sound
  • Sound Physics: Explore concepts like frequency, amplitude, and wavelength.
  • Acoustics: Learn how sound interacts with different environments.
2.2 Core Audio Concepts
  • Key Terms: Decibels, dynamic range, phase, and psychoacoustics.
  • Practical Exercises:
  • Blindfold listening to improve auditory perception.
  • Analyzing real-world sounds.
2.3 Digital Sound Processing
  • DSP Basics: Learn about digital representation of sound.
  • Noise & Distortion: Understand their role in creative sound design.
4.1 The Basics of Music
  • Notes & Scales: Learn major, minor, and modes.
  • Chord Progressions: Understand common structures used in popular music.
4.2 Rhythm Fundamentals
  • Time Signatures: Explore 4/4, 3/4, and other common rhythms.
  • Drum Programming:
  • Using Drum Racks and MIDI sequencing.
  • Adding groove and human feel.
4.3 Practical Music Application
  • Creative Writing: Learn call-and-response techniques for melodies.
  • Homework: Develop melodies and progressions for 5 mini-projects.
5.1 Sound Design and Synthesis
  • Introduction to Synthesis: Subtractive, FM, Wavetable, and Additive synthesis.
  • Design Basics: Create leads, bass, and pad sounds.
  • Advanced Design: Explore evolving textures and layered sounds.
5.2 Sampling
  • Simpler vs. Sampler: Differences and applications.
  • Manipulation Techniques: Adjust loop points, envelopes, and filters.
5.3 Structuring Tracks
  • Arrangement Techniques: Break down existing songs to study their structure.
  • Project Work: Students create two fully arranged tracks by the end of this module.
6.1 Audio Effects
  • Dynamic Effects: Compression, gating, limiting, and parallel compression.
  • EQ Techniques:
  • Corrective and creative EQing.
  • Understanding frequency ranges for different instruments.
6.2 MIDI Effects and Automation
  • Effects: Arpeggiators, chord generators, and scale tools.
  • Automation: Controlling parameters for dynamic tracks.
6.3 Audio Effect Racks
  • Custom Chains: Learn to build and organize complex racks.
  • Practical Project: Create and document personalized audio racks.
7.1 Mixing and Mastering
  • Mixing Basics: Balancing levels and using effects like EQ and compression.
  • Mastering: Learn limiting and loudness optimization for final tracks.
7.2 Final Projects
  • Students present:
  • 3 mixed and mastered tracks.
  • Personalized creative blocks and breakthroughs.
7.3 Feedback & Review
  • Constructive peer and mentor feedback.
  • Strategies for ongoing improvement.
Module 1: Introduction & Orientation
1.1 Course Overview
  • Course Goals: Understand what youâ€™ll achieve by the end of the program.
  • Expectations: Learn the skills to transition from an explorer to a budding music producer.
1.2 Setting Up for Success
  • Equipment Optimization: Learn how to set up your studio effectively.
  • Buying Guide: Get recommendations for essential gear, including MIDI controllers, audio interfaces, and headphones.
1.3 First Steps in Ableton
  • Software Installation: Understand system requirements and installation steps.
  • Getting Started:
  • Abletonâ€™s interface: Session View and Arrangement View.
  • Basic navigation: Browser, clips, and beats.
Module 2: Audio Fundamentals
Module 3: Ableton Essentials
3.1 Mastering the Interface
  • Session View vs. Arrangement View: Learn the differences and applications.
  • Clip Management: Creating, editing, and organizing MIDI and audio clips.
3.2 Navigating the Browser
  • Components: Categories, Places, Collections.
  • Efficient Use: Filtering and tagging for faster workflows.
3.3 Ableton Tools and Features
  • Push Integration: Hands-on with Ableton Push (2 or 3).
  • Templates: Creating reusable setups for consistent workflows.
Module 4: Music Theory for Producers
Module 5: Production Techniques
Module 6: Advanced Tools and Techniques
Module 7: Final Track Development
